Award.AwardTitle: Wavelet Analysis of High Spatial Resolution Imagery for Urban Mapping Using Infinite Scale Decomposition Techniques

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The importance of dynamic and complex interactions among urban land use, land-cover change, and global environmental change is well recognized. Despite significant advances in geographic information science and technology, however, effectively categorizing digital remote sensing data into detailed urban land categories remains a challenge. This research project aims to develop a frequency-based, multi-scale classification algorithm using overcomplete wavelet transforms that can generate higher-level spatial arrangements of objects and features for detailed urban land categorization. The investigator will seek to enhance spatial modeling and concepts that describe spatial association, spatial pattern, spatial regression, and segregation by adding decomposition procedures that can extract spatial features in different directions at infinite scale. Selected wavelet transforms to be used in the project include a series of Daubechies and Coiflets. The project's multi-faceted approach will permit the new algorithm to be used for any level of scale, from large-scale air photos to coarse-resolution MODIS and AVHRR data. Five distinct normalization procedures will be used to prevent large-range features from dominating the distance measure. The performance of a minimum distance classifier will be evaluated for texture classification using the computed texture feature value of the sub-images. In addition, the Mahalanobis distance rule will be employed to account for the variability of classes. Finally, three classification decision rules will be developed. The project is expected to result in a new wavelet-based framework that provides scientific evidence for the role of spatial properties and frequencies of geo-objects in different directions at infinite scale. This framework and algorithm will be made publicly available for performing image classification effectively in remotely sensed imagery.

This project will enable researchers, modelers, and analysts to differentiate among urban land-cover and land-use types and to categorize detailed urban land data. It is expected to generate maps that are more accurate, thereby improving mapping and analysis procedures. The new geospatial frequency-based framework and methods will help improve semi-automated and automated analysis procedures. The tools from this project will be versatile and can be applied to a wide variety of other land cover, land-use types (i.e., agriculture, rangeland, forest, wetlands, and coastal zones) and conditions (i.e., drought, fire fuel concentrations, desertification, flood risk, and coastal erosion), thereby making it very useful for more than just urban planning. Furthermore, it will advance geographic information science by building a foundation for methodological innovations in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project develops a new frequency-based classification framework and algorithms using overcomplete decomposition to identify macro-scale and micro-scale land use land cover (LULC) types. It uses normalization procedures, decomposition options, classifiers, and classification decision rules compatible with the overcomplete algorithms to identify LULC categories more effectively. The development of wavelet-based algorithms (WAVE-Class) was completed using Matlab programming language in December 2015. The algorithm uses an graphical user interface (GUI) that allows users to select different wavelets (Daubechies and Coiflets series), block size, wavelet scale levels, satellite bands, texture features, (Shannon, Log, Energy), approximation (one approximation or all approximation), normalization (one normalization or all normalization), normalization rule (within band normalization, all bands normalization, level wise normalization), decision rule (band minimum rule, majority rule, all bands minimum rule), and distance rule (minimum distance, Mahalanobis distance). The new wavelet overcomplete algorithm incorporates a covariance matrix into the wavelet-based classifiers to determine if a classifier that takes the variability of classes into account is more effective than a minimum distance classifier. The project examines the effectiveness of the WAVE-Class algorithm in comparison to a widely used classical approach (maximum likelihood). Three image subsets of QuickBird data (park, commercial, and rural) over a central region in the city of Phoenix were used. The maximum likelihood classifier produced < 78.29% overall accuracies for all three image subsets. The WAVE-Class algorithm achieved high overall accuracies—95.05% for the commercial subset (Kappa = 0.94), 93.71% for the park subset (Kappa = 0.93), and 89.33% for the rural subset (Kappa = 0.86). Results demonstrate that the WAVE-Class algorithm is effective in identifying detailed urban land cover types in high spatial-resolution data.

 

To examine if the WAVE-Class algorithm is effective for mapping LULC classes in medium-resolution data, we evaluate the overall accuracies of outcomes of all possible combinations of both high- and medium-resolution data classification parameters available with the WAVE-Class algorithm. We attempt to identify several LULC classes that are normally impractical or problematic to identify (i.e., open space-mountain, active agriculture, golf course, industrial/commercial/transportation, high density residential, medium density residential, low density residential, open soil, and open water). We observe a 7.14% increase in the overall accuracy averaged across scale level as the block size increases from 3 to 5. The overall accuracy remained high when the block size reached 7. There is an inconsistent trend in the overall accuracy as scale levels change when block size is held constant. While the overall accuracy was higher at a higher scale level for block size 3, an opposite trend was observed for block sizes 5 and 7—the overall accuracy declined as the scale level increased. However, the score change in response to changing scale was somewhat negligible compared to that for changing block size. Despite the variations, our wavelet analysis method achieved the highest overall accuracy among the algorithm used in the analysis (an average of 74.96%), followed by maximum likelihood (58.9%), mahalanobis distance (52.77%), and minimum distance (46.95%). Even the lowest score from all the wavelet combinations (block size 3, scale level 1) was 9.72% higher than the maximum likelihood method, 15.85% higher than the mahalanobis distance method, and 21.67% higher than the minimum distance method, making our algorithm superior to the conventional classification methods.
